I started with about $25k with my main investments being $AAPL $SPY $INTC $SPOT just to name a few, but over the years I deposited 1-5k over various different tickers based on my belief in their fundamentals. Overall there’s about 50-60k of my own money in there. The rest is growth.

author: SnipahShot
body:
I think you might not know the difference between insiders and institutions. Insiders are officers and directors of the companies. Institutions are hedge funds.

Retail investors probably don't have the money to keep it going up, but hedges do.

It isn't that hard to check what he is saying about insiders selling. Insider selling means that they believe the current price is too high for their company, otherwise they would have kept the stocks.

Look at a few companies and their insider activity -

Tesla: 10 shares were bought in the last 12 months. Almost 9.2mil shares sold in that time.

AMD: 0 shares were bought in the last 12 months. Almost 3mil shares sold in that time.

Nvidia: 206k shares were bought in the last 12 months. Almost 1.5mil shares sold in that time.

Moderna: 0 shares were bought in the last 12 months. 13.6mil shares were sold in that time.

&#x200B;

Now let's look at companies whose value didn't spike.

Analog Devices: 840k shares were bought in the last 12 months. 310k shares were sold in that time.

Intel: 430k shares were bought in the last 12 months. 250k were sold in that time.

Norwegian Cruise: 480k shares were bought in the last 12 months. 370k shares were sold in the last 3 months.

&#x200B;

It does not indicate whether the market will crash, but it indicates what insiders think of the valuation of the company they are part of.

author: hexydes
body:
This is *exactly* why you invest in infrastructure and innovative industries during the good times. We need our computer/Internet revolution of the 21st-century. We ran into this in the 1970s-80s too, where inflation was high, wage growth was low, and economic activity was treading water. Then we had the computer revolution with Microsoft, Apple, Cisco, Intel, and about 100 other players that pulled us through the 80s when rates were hiked way up. Then rates came back down to something reasonable (i.e. not 0%) and we had the Internet revolution with Amazon, AOL (lol I know), Google, Facebook, and others.

But *all of that* was made possible because we made big investments during the 40s-60s in things like computers, transistors, Arpanet, etc. These things take time to pay off, some of them don't pan out, but that's why you:

1. Invest.
2. Diversify.

Over the last 40 years, the investment in infrastructure and basic research has been whittled away by the Republican party. They constantly gripe about "socialism...or communism...one of them" and not spending money. Then they turn around and spend $1 trillion on the War on Drugs and $3 trillion on wars in the Middle East. That's $4 trillion that could have gone to infrastructure investments. And then when the Democratic party tries to get $2 trillion in new infrastructure investments over a decade, suddenly it's back to "THAT'S COMMUNISM AND WE CAN'T AFFORD IT!"

We should be absolutely pouring resources into clean energy infrastructure, broadband access, and biomedical technology right now. And yet we have to sit here and watch Republicans (and two Democrats) sit on their hands and scream about "NO COMMUNISM! TOO MUCH MONEY!"

Clock is ticking for the US...

author: porncrank
body:
You missed the point of the timeline — the private sector (Apple, Microsoft, Cisco, Intel) was made possible by decades of government investments that were not directly profitable at the time (computers, transistors, arpanet). The relationship played out again with NASA and SpaceX — there would be no market for SpaceX if NASA hadn’t spent millions creating a viable market for satellites.

So what unprofitable endeavor is the government putting money into now that will pay off for the country in 20 years? The private sector can not and will not work unprofitably on such a long timeline, which is what government spending is all about.

author: msnf
body:
I'm just about 8 years into my investing journey. Here are some of my milestones, though YMMV:

**Year 0-1**

* Being surprised that a stock beat on earnings and went down.

* Buying an unprofitable stock on hype, watching it go down 10-20% and hoping it goes up so you can sell it for a smaller loss (TWTR for me).

* Wondering how you're ever supposed to get to 30 stocks, when you're sitting at 5 and tempted to go all in on your biggest holding.

* Reading lots of Buffet/value stuff and memorizing cliche quotes.

* Caring at all about technical analysis, stop losses, shorting, dividends, splits or the specific price of a share.

* Buying stocks because of M&A.

**Years 2-3**

* Buying a large cap value stock that went down and doing the surprised pikachu when it keeps going down. (INTC).

* Selling your first double-bagger for a profit... and watching it 5x in the future. (W)

* Learning about factors, Sharpes, Shiller P/Es, Buffet ratios and worrying about macros in general.

* Thinking about sectors, fundamentals, valuation ratios, growth etc.

* Spotting an ETF that's been beating you (with lower risk) all this time.

* Learning how to buy on the dip.

**Years 4-6**

* Being ok selling a long-term loser.

* Feeling good about buying a broad-based ETF.

* Diversifying by choice and not necessity.

* Not playing earnings and focusing on the long term.

* Holding all your capital gains to long-term.

* Thinking about share dilutions, buybacks, cash flows, cap ex., moats and network effects.

* Kind of half-assed doing some DCFs and valuations, and then moving on.

**Years 7+**

* Thinking about position sizes, correlations, macros, yields and rates.

* Playing small positions in earnings again because it's cheap beta lol.

* Sticking with allocations even if they're uncomfortable. Wondering why you'd ever go 25+% on one move.

* Searching out guidance on the 10Q.

* Being OK selling on the dip.

author: Ja_Nee_Misschien
body:
Intel is mainly behind because they failed to order a lot of EUV machines early unlike TSMC and Samsung. This can be fixed by spending a bigger share of the profits on capex and buying a lot of these advanced EUV machines themselves and that is exactly what they are going to do and what pissed of some investors. Intel announced they will be the first to receive the next iteration of even more advanced EUV machines soon.

By being a foundry Intel can use all their IP for their customers. This will give them an advantage over TSMC and Samson for a sizable chunk of the market. Simply because they can throw in this IP so customers can design product only intel can make. Their packaging techniques are not the same as those of TSMC and at least a sizable share of the market will benefit from these. I'm not going to claim they will steamroll TSMC but they will be able to take market share. It's a new market. It will be the same as AMD doubling their data center business by taking a few percentages of market share from Intel. In the foundry business TSMC will be like Intel and Intel will be like AMD.

As a foundry you can make whatever the client designs. Intel clearly stated they will go for a mix and match strategy where clients can combine external IP like ARM with Intel IP like packaging or networking. X86 will always have a place but Intel clearly accepted that it's not only x86 anymore and they are adapting.

author: EtadanikM
body:
Not really crazy. I mean, yes, it's hard to predict how high it'd go, but the trend of investing in chips, CPUs, and other advanced hardware is a follow up to present day economic and geopolitical news - ie the competition between the West and China, which is centered around chips; and the global chip shortage, which is the result of various supply issues, that is factoring into their price.

The market might seem random at times, but it's rational in the *long-term*. Global trends eventually transform into market facts. 

For example:

* Peak oil + climate change -> rise of electric vehicle and new energy companies

* Money printing + global corporate taxes -> rise of bit coin and other ways to avoid taxes / hedge against inflation

* Chip supply issues + competition vs. China -> rise of chip companies

What's hard in all this is picking the winners. Just because chip companies are on the rise doesn't mean all of them are doing well. Example: Intel. Just because people are dumping more money into bit coin, doesn't mean all of the currencies are doing well. Just because the market is loving electric vehicles, doesn't mean all electric vehicle companies are having gains like Tesla.

The noise is there and will always be there. You either live with it and buy into an ETF and accept modest gains, or you try to gamble on which company is going to take it all. That's where the challenge is.

author: cdazzo1
body:
>THE issue I have with this is not only do I want to know NYTs motives,

[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sQN4c3uN\_tA](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=sQN4c3uN_tA)

It's incredibly long but it is a much better answer than I can give, but I'll still try to give you the cliff notes version.  

Yuri Bezmenov is often referred to as a "former KGM agent".  But he wasn't really an agent, although he obviously helped them.  He was a "journalist" but his job description was mostly to "entertain" American visitors.  These Americans were carefully vetted before being invited to Russia and upon arrival he did things like get them drunk, make Russia look really good, and try to get them in slightly compromised situations.  Things like pictures of them in the same room as prostitutes or drinking too much so they'd be unsure of what they did the previous day/night and if they said or did something wrong.  He'd then use this as leverage to get them to say favorable things about Russia in the US.

That was it.  It was all about perception.  That was the majority of KGB "spy" operations.

When it comes to Evergrand, cui bono? China.  So whether intentionally carrying weight for China or just useful idiots victimized by CCP intel operations, NYT is carrying water for the **CCP who desperately wants to unload assets before the rest of the world catches on**.  This is the exact **same play they ran for the pandemic** when they vacuumed up PPE across the globe while denying human to human transmission.

The screenshot says that organization (eg one part of intel.) 

It’s Q4, they probably already hit their hiring budget agreed to last year and are waiting for the approval of their next year budget to re-open hiring. 

This is bog standard corporate stuff.

author: boneywankenobi
body:
Farmers are becoming consolidated yeah, but they operate still on thin margins.  And we actually tried to pitch this to agri futs traders who were our customers for other ag intel products a few years ago and they didn't care.  Weren't even trying to sell it, just gauge interest.  This was first hand feedback from the potential customers. 

So you say I don't understand the usefulness, I'd say most people overestimate it.  I led the project to do this professionally at a $100m+ company.  Realtime data is nice and all, but how are you going to monetize it?  Gotta pay for R&D and the imagery, then act on the imagery in a way you couldn't do otherwise to generate a profit.  Oh, and it can't be specific enough that going a week without data will screw it up because clouds are gonna happen.

I actually worked on the tech and pitching of the listed commercializing ideas listed as a customer of $DMYQ for 3 years, and our existing customers didn't want it.  Not oil, not ag, not traders, not hedgies.  There is some demand out there, but it's niche, few, and far between.  No where near what they say.

author: JonA3531
body:
Got in AMD at around $4. Sold around $45 unfortunately.

Thought process? They are the only other CPU and GPU maker aside from Intel (CPU only) and Nvidia (GPU only), and they got exclusive contract with Playstation and Xbox.

But in a hindsight, it was a bit of a gamble. Their current success was entirely hinged on their new chip architecture design (Ryzen) to be a good one and Intel to screw up their chip fabrications.

If Ryzen ended up being mediocre or Intel could still compete with TSMC with their fabs, AMD would not have been as successful as they are now.

author: Ja_Nee_Misschien
body:
Everyone know TSMC is using a different naming scheme to make it look like their nodes are more advanced. It's true that Intel had some delays and therefore some of their designs got stuck waiting on the new nodes. 

The last time we have been looking at relative older designs made on older nodes. People seem to believe this os all Intel has but this is obviously not true. They have been developing new IP just like the rest of the industry.

Rocket lake is made on Intel 14nm and their chips offer better performance than similarly priced AMD chips made on 7nm. 

Alder lake is made on 10nm and outperforms even the more expensive AMD chips made on 7nm.

Either Intel is able to make incredible designs that beat chip designs by AMD even if they are made on more advance nodes or TSMC wasn't really hones when naming the nodes. We'll see when Intel get's their EUV machines.

What has changed is new leadership with a lot of technical expertise getting everything moving again.

author: ese_men
body: Intel. The AMD and NVDA moves have been off the charts. The new Intel will focus on foundry and Software. They just caught up to AMD, next they will move into NVDA's turf with GPUs early next year. Intel makes their own chips, so they can sell as many as they can make (since i think demand will persist). Best of all they're not constrained by TSM. I think a 3x over the next few years is possible. People have no allegiance, it's all about making money. If Intel executes they could get the AMD/NVDA stock treatment. Maybe a trillion dollar company by the end of the decade.

author: PepeMcPeperson
body:
I am mostly a conservative investor so for the moment i'm only invested in INTC and texas instruments. If i had to open any other positions i would mostly go to the foundry businesses like TSMC or Samsung. 

I feel intel, samsung and tsmc are the more sure bets and have been the only ones able to participate in Moore's law the past few years making the leading edge really a oligoply.

Intel since it is traing really cheap at a sub 10 PE with the companies management expecting the revenue to increase by 10% per year and margins only decreasing only 2-3%. With dividend and buybacks combined they return aboud 7% per year if their revenue of profits wouldn't increase which they almost certainly will.

Samsung makes most of it's money from it's foundy business and retail electronics. If it's foundry business' orders decrease they can fill up the remaining space with their own needs. (same as intel)

Tsmc is the real leader in the industry with customers having reserved all capacity for years ahead.

For price targets i would recomend [this DFCF tool](https://tracktak.com/dashboard). You fill in what revenue growth you expect the comming years, how much the ROIC is and what margins you expect.

NVDA and AMD seem like really good companies but they are priced for perfection.

author: Wazoo_destroyer
body:
1. Intel has been heavily supporting their share price, where would it be without them? Sub $40?
2. Their p/e ratio reflects their market saturation, who are they going to steal market share from? They are the incumbent.
3. And they will need every cent to build new fabs.
4. Never say never, Intel is going to have to take on massive debt, in addition to the 30B they carry at present, to fund IDM2.0. If the CFO is looking for cash the dividend is easy pickings.

Their new weird CEO has stated intc is aiming for leadership in 2025, 3-4 years away. One thing to remember is this super cycle aside, the semiconductor biz is cyclical, boom and bust. In 3 or 4 years when demand drops off and both TSMC and INTC have built massive chip foundry capacity, where will the customers go? To the foundry with the best process. Whoever has overbuilt will suffer.

author: Wazoo_destroyer
body:
> The nm stuff isn't really accurate for any of them anymore so not worried about a rebrand.

Gate leakage and ultimately performance per watt is the real measure of a process. If one compares Tsmc and Intel fabbed processors on what both call 7nm, the tsmc silicon is easily better.

author: simplysufficient88
body:
To be entirely fair here, this whole thing’s based on a really bad article title. Everyone’s quoting the CNN article that makes it sound as though the WFP director was claiming all you’d need is $6 billion to solve all hunger. When the actual statement he made was that it would help to fix the growth in world hunger issues we’ve seen recently, not that it would solve hunger entirely. He very specifically mentions that this is a one time donation that would help 42 million people that need immediate aid, but that wouldn’t be a long term fix. Even the CNN article itself now has a correction at the very bottom acknowledging this was a misleading title. 

Obviously this is all an over simplification of the issue and you can’t just throw money at it to fix it, but the point he was trying to make wasn’t that one donation from one billionaire would permanently solve all hunger but that a one time donation from MULTIPLE of the world’s wealthiest individuals would help save a lot of people in the short term. I think that’s a pretty massive difference.

author: Tfarecnim
body:
Yeah no, there's way too many accounts trying to push this crap stock right before a share unlock.  Stop it.

Ask yourself a question, if it is really such a great company, then why did 80% of shareholders turn in their shares for $10 rather than hold on to them?  There's a reason they are so high, and it's not because it's a great company at a low price.

This play isn't new and has been seen by many previously low float deSPACs such as OPAD, SPIR and IRNT.

As for my play?  I don't know when the unlock will happen, but I suspect it will be sometime between now and December, so in about a week or so, I will be picking up 15P and waiting for the inevitable drop that's implied by the warrant-common gap.

Remember that the PIPE has a $10 cost basis and unlike dumb Redditors, they will take a guaranteed 80% return on an investment and won't diamond hand it to 0.  And relative to the current float, the PIPE is huge so the drop will be very big, possibly even below 10.

Seriously, after GME everyone is always looking for the next "squeeze", but chances are, if you've just heard of it it's too late.


We are not here to carry your bags for you, stop gambling on garbage hoping for an unrealistic return and pick a solid company like SOFI.  Seriously, 2023 25c LEAPs on SOFI will print better than 90% of these shitty squeeze plays.  Sure it might not be the 500% returns in 2 weeks that people seem to be hoping for, but at least you won't be -70% after a month bagholding something that someone told you would go higher.

author: fugov
body:
>It seems like information is never free and it feels like everyone has a secret they want to sell you.

This is exactly the case. These people were at some point in time in the same place as you are now. They have put in a lot of work and probably lost a lot of money to get where they are now. Now they know a "shortcut" that they can teach you about, well not directly, just enough to keep you intrigued.

Problem is, even if you buy their stuff, you will never be as good as them because what is missing is the foundation that they have build and the exposure to the topic that they got. It pays off to work and learn for yourself, even tho it is painful and dagerous and tedious af.

You will never become a great musician, artist, programmer or investor by watching videos. What will get you there is reading books and grinding. Grinding, grinding, grinding.

And most people are not willing to do that. So doing that already will bring you in the top 1% of people who COULD be successful.

author: productivitydev
body:
Do you think company as a whole has value? If not would you give any company away for free? And if the company has value, why wouldn't small piece of that have value?

But of course... I understand why you are asking this question. Because if you just buy a stock and you let it stay there, unless the company gives dividends you will receive nothing in return. So you agree that a company that gives dividends does have value? Let's say a company that gives 10% of dividends each year, will make you back that money in 10 years and from there everything else is a bonus.

Now. What is the reason why every company doesn't give dividends? The reason is growth. They and their shareholders both think it's better to invest the potential dividends back into growing the company. 

But the company always will have "potential" to give out dividends, once they decide they don't need to grow anymore - they could start giving out dividends, but meanwhile you can think of dividends as constantly being automatically invested back into the company, however due to company growing the potential also increases an you can still cash out the "dividends" by selling the stock at higher price due to potential of dividends having been grown.

Does that make sense?

author: CalyShadezz
body:
LCID is people looking for TSLA 2.0.

I think most here understand that TSLA does a lot beyond their EV production and the market is pricing in a very optimistic future versus their other ventures (as well as increased auto sales).

LCID is a luxury EV supplier. They have some positives in their tech but overall they're just an EV company. They're somewhere in the ballpark of 10k preorders.

Now compare them to a company like Ford who has a similar market cap at the moment. Ford does about 4m in New vehicle sales per year. 

Think about that. The market is very irrational right now but nothing justifies LCID's current valuation besides "Bro EV is the future, get the next TSLA before you miss out."

I expect LCID will keep running tho...the market seems to love high valuations with zero justification.

author: Olgrateful-IW
body:
Your entire make believe scenario belies the fact that every other first world free nation pays better and closer to (and above) a living wage and the world didn’t end as a result. Every little business didn’t shut down. 

It turns out when people have actual purchasing power instead of barely affording the means to live (or not affording it) despite working full time that they are then able to support the very businesses they can’t afford to shop at now. The small ones.

What doesn’t track is the American attitude that “this is the best it could work” that you seem to have when other places are literally doing it all better. Better wages, economies for the middle class, healthcare, and overall financial security.

The irony of what you are worried about is currently happening under the system we have now. But due to a total lack of regulation. Giant companies crushing start ups. Giant companies treating their employees poorly. Monopolies and to big to fail due to lack of regulations and mergers being allowed that shouldn’t. 

Unregulated capitalism is causing all the things you FEAR fair wages would create. 

Isn’t that funny? But I’m out as this obviously not going anywhere productive.

author: Itsnotjustadream
body:
This is EXACTLY whats happening at my fortune 100 except last year they cut benefits and bonus effectively reducing our total comp by about 13-15 percent (the benefits were stellar.. WERE).  This year they were all SHOCKED that attrition in highly skilled areas hit 15-18% so to combat it they took their sweet ass time and decided pay raises were in order.  The CEO sent out a company wide email basically saying expect a conversation with your manager as we're making changes.

They touched only the areas with the highest attrition (about 60% of workforce) and the starting salary.  We now have folks who have been here 1-5 years who are going to make the same as a new hire.  We now have folks who have been here 10 years who are going to be making $1-$5 more than a new hire.  We now have specialized technical experts getting paid the same as a college hire.  Good luck if the bonus this year sucks because the folks I hang out with who were absolutely dedicated to making this a place we retired from are all tooling up and looking.

author: Life_is_Truff
body: Wait, girls have brains now? Thanks article, this is very insightful hahaha

author: cnelson711
body: I'm all for house prices raising at or near the inflation rate.  But if my home value went up $100k because of the local market, it'd be bittersweet.  Yes, I picked the right market and am now a beneficiary of that market's appreciated prices.  But it also means my kids would have harder times affording a house.  It means if I wanted to move to a bigger house in the same area I'd have to pay a lot more.  It means more property taxes soon.
